the inner segments and the external surface, much more direct
than that which they profess through the series of segments
which form the [?] spire. The existence of this
system of canals, has been verified, not merely in Nummulites
by M M D'Archiac and Haime, but also in several recent types;
thus Prof Williamson has detected it in <u>Amphistegina</u> 
and <u>Nonionina</u> and more recently in <u>Faugasina</u> (.which
furnishes one of the most remarkable examples of it); which
M Carter of Bombay has discovered it in <u>Operculina</u>. My
 own <s>labours</s> enquiries, which have been carried on with scarcely an
intermission, from the time of my first discovery of this
remarkable point of structure, have been specially directed
to the determination of the extent to which it presents itself
in the different sections of the group, and of its value as a
distinctive character; and I think that I shall be able to
show that it is a feature of the utmost importance, the
presence of which marks an elevation of type, and its absence
<u>a corresponding degradation. It is much to be regretted, that the</u>
